channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Dozens Killed After Attack Near Aid Stations in Gaza
item.description: Dozens of people were killed near two aid-distribution stations in the Gaza Strip, the latest setback to a new humanitarian relief operation backed by Israel and the US as a way of sidelining Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Fares Alghoul, Fadwa Hodali

media:content.media:description: Injured Palestinians are being brought to the Nasser Hospital for their treatment process after Israeli soldiers opened fire at Palestinians trying to reach the points where US aid is distributed west of Rafah city in the southern Gaza Strip, in Khan Yunis, Gaza on June 1.

item.title: President Trump to Double Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum
item.description: President Trump set to double tariffs to 50% on steel and aluminum imports. Bloomberg's Shaquille Omari explains how this connects to the US Steel-Nippon Steel deal and why some are against the agreement. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ukraine Drone Strikes Hit Nuclear Bombers Deep Inside Russia
item.description: Ukrainian drones hit several Russian strategic airfields, including a military base deep in eastern Siberia, while Moscow launched one of its longest drone and missile attacks against Kyiv, escalating tensions ahead of crucial peace talks this week.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: A Tupolev Tu-95 strategic bomber aircraft stands on display at the MAKS International Aviation and Space Salon at Zhukovsky International Airport in Moscow, Russia, on Tuesday, Aug. 27, 2019. The Kremlin hinted at possible talks over new arms deals between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Turkish leader Recep Tayyip Erdogan when the two leaders meet at the international air show near Moscow.

item.title: Bessent Says US Will Never Default as Congress Faces Endgame
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the US “is never going to default” as the deadline for increasing the federal debt ceiling gets closer.
item.dc:creator: Tony Czuczka

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, US, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Bessent said that US regulators this summer may ease a rule that’s served as a constraint on banks’ trading in the $29 trillion Treasuries market. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Big Tech Is Back in S&P 500 Driver’s Seat as Profit Engines Hum
item.description: The same technology giants that helped drag the S&P 500 to the brink of a bear market in April are giving the recovery in US equities some legs.
item.dc:creator: Jeran Wittenstein, Ryan Vlastelica

media:content.media:description: An Nvidia Corp. GB200 Grace Blackwell superchip on display at the SK Hynix Inc. booth during the Computex conference in Taipei, Taiwan, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. Computex kicked off Monday in Taipei, and as in years past drew industry chieftains from Nvidia Corp.'s Jensen Huang and Qualcomm Inc.'s Cristiano Amon to Young Liu of Foxconn, which makes the bulk of the world's iPhones and Nvidia servers.

item.title: Australian House Prices Continue to Climb After RBA Rate Cut
item.description: Australian home prices climbed for a fourth straight month, driven by a second interest rate cut by the country’s central bank and expectations more will follow later this year.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Newly built houses in the Caddens suburb of Sydney, Australia, on Saturday, Sept. 28, 2024. Property consultancy CoreLogic Inc. will release September home-value data on Oct. 1.

item.title: Ukraine Faces Sustained Russian Barrage Before Planned Talks
item.description: Ukraine came under one of the longest barrages from Russian missiles and drones early Sunday, with air sirens lasting for more then 9 hours, ahead of planned talks between Kyiv and Moscow this week.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: KYIV, UKRAINE - APRIL 6: Kyiv residents shelter in subway amid a Russian ballistic missiles' strike on April 6, 2025 in Kyiv, Ukraine. In the morning, the Russian army launched a mass strike on the Ukrainian capital with ballistic missiles, which were intercepted by Air Defense Forces. However, missile fragments fell in three districts of the city, Darnytskyi, Obolonskyi and Solomyanskyi, resulting in damage or destruction of non-residential buildings and cars. In order to protect themselves and their families, people go to shelters during air attacks - to subway stations, buildings' basements, underground parking lots or underpasses. (Photo by Yan Dobronosov/Global Images Ukraine via Getty Images) Photographer: Global Images Ukraine/Global Images Ukraine

item.title: Taiwan Central Bank Warns Exporters Against Currency Speculation
item.description: Taiwan’s Central Bank strengthened its warning to local trading companies over their currency purchases as it seeks once again to tamp down speculation on foreign exchange markets and maintain the stability of the Taiwan dollar.
item.dc:creator: Chien-Hua Wan, Betty Hou

media:content.media:description: The exchange rate of the Taiwan dollar against various currencies displayed at a currency exchange in Taipei, Taiwan, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. The Taiwan dollar surged as much as 4.8% on Monday, fueled by concerns over the US dollar’s outlook and speculation that Taiwan may let its currency gain as it seeks a trade deal with the US.

item.title: Mexico Elects Judges Among Scores of Little-Known Candidates
item.description: Mexican voters head to the polls on Sunday to begin picking judges in an unprecedented election that could give President Claudia Sheinbaum broad influence over a revamped judiciary, the only branch of government her party doesn’t control.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: A banner of President Claudia Sheinbaum in Iztapalapa, Mexico City

item.title: IndiGo Orders 30 New Airbus Jets, Partners Delta in Global Push
item.description: Discount-carrier IndiGo doubled its order of Airbus SE A350 widebody aircraft and signed a code-sharing accord with three major international airlines, as the Indian market leader pushes ahead with its global expansion effort.
item.dc:creator: Siddharth Vikram Philip, Mihir Mishra

media:content.media:description: An Airbus SE A320 aircraft, operated by IndiGo, a unit of InterGlobe Aviation Ltd., prepares to land at Indira Gandhi International Airport in New Delhi, India, on Wednesday, Oct. 23, 2024. IndiGo is scheduled to release earnings results on Oct. 25.

item.title: Carry Trades Roar Back Into Favor as Emerging Currencies Rally
item.description: Emerging market carry trades are taking off again, as currency volatility subsides amid signs President Donald Trump’s aggressive tariffs may not get fully enacted.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Bosley, Malavika Kaur Makol

item.title: How Will Funding Cuts Affect Innovation?
item.description: We explore the vital relationship between US research universities and the broader economy. International students play an important part in the pipeline for universities and the innovation that begins at higher education institutions. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ukrainian Drones Strike Four Military Airfields in Russia
item.description: Ukrainian drones hit several Russian military airfields Sunday, including Belaya military base deep in eastern Siberia, according to a source with Ukraine’s Security Service.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: A "Vampire" strike drone during a presentation of drone military hardware of the Unmanned Systems Force of the Ukraine Armed Forces in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday, June 11, 2024. Ukraine demonstrated various types of remotely-operated unmanned robotic systems used by the Ukrainian military. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: Delta Sees Demand Ticking Up After ‘Lumpy’ First Months
item.description: Delta Air Lines CEO Ed Bastian is more confident about demand in the second half of the year due to price-sensitive passengers in the US showing restraint in recent months amid a worsening economic climate. Demand should “tick up a bit” in the period, Bastian said in an interview with Bloomberg Television in New Delhi on Sunday. That’s after Delta suffered weakness in bookings predominantly in the US market and among leisure travelers in its main cabin earlier this year, he said in an interview with Bloomberg's Guy Johnson. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Airline Industry Benefiting From Lower Oil Price, IATA Head Says
item.description: The global aviation industry is benefiting from lower oil prices because they’re bringing down the cost of kerosene, the head of the IATA industry association said.
item.dc:creator: Guy Johnson, Benedikt Kammel

media:content.media:description: A passenger aircraft, operated by EasyJet Plc, taking off at London Luton Airport in Luton, U.K., on Monday, July 25, 2022. EasyJet are due to report their latest earnings on Tuesday.

item.title: Quant Traders That Dominate US Options Market Move in on Europe
item.description: The option market makers that dominate US trading are taking a bigger share of volume in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Christian Dass

item.title: China Home Sales Slump Drags On as Deflation Eats Into Incomes
item.description: China’s residential property sales continued to fall on in May, signaling the real estate slump is still weighing on an economy that’s under pressure from deflation and trade tensions.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Emma Dong

media:content.media:description: Residential buildings under construction at the China Vanke Co. Elegant Lifestyle project in Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, April 17, 2024.

item.title: Europe Stocks Stage World-Beating Rally as Trade War Backfires
item.description: Europe’s equities have emerged clear winners worldwide as the region’s economic outlook brightens at a time when President Donald Trump’s trade war hobbles US financial markets.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani, Julien Ponthus

media:content.media:description: Stock prices on the trading floor of the Euronext NV stock exchange in Paris, France, on Tuesday, April 15, 2025. Stocks rose as US President Donald Trump floated a potential pause in auto tariffs, providing further relief to the market after he suspended levies on some consumer electronics.

item.title: US Job Growth Is Seen Moderating on Shifting Trade Policy
item.description: The pace of US hiring probably slowed in May, with employers focusing on containing costs as households become a bit more guarded and businesses reconsidered investment plans against a backdrop of shifting trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Commuters board a Red line Metro train at the Metro Center metro stop in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. A House Republican introduced legislation to block federal funding for the Washington Metrorail system unless it is renamed the "Trump Train," Axios reports.

item.title: Canadian Wildfires Force Oilsands Evacuations, Stop Oil Flows
item.description: Raging Western Canadian wildfires that have forced thousands of people from their homes are now also prompting evacuations from oilsands projects in northern Alberta.
item.dc:creator: Geoffrey Morgan

media:content.media:description: Wildfire smoke above Highway 97 near Trutch, British Columbia on May 30. Photographer: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin/Bloomberg

item.title: Vietnam Proposes $2b Northeastern Casino Resort: VnExpress
item.description: Vietnam’s Ministry of Finance is proposing an investment policy for a 51.5 trillion dong ($1.98 billion) luxury casino complex in the northeastern province of Quang Ninh, home to Unesco World Heritage Site Ha Long Bay, VnExpress International news website reported.
item.dc:creator: John Boudreau

item.title: White House Prepares to Ease Rules for Big Banks, Politico Says
item.description: The Trump administration is preparing to ease rules imposed on the largest US banks following the 2008 financial crisis, Politico said, citing people with knowledge of the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Alan Goldstein

media:content.media:description: A pedestrians crosses a street in front of Deutsche Bank Center in New York, US, on Tuesday, Jan. 28, 2025. Ever since the global financial crisis, in an attempt to align pay to shareholder returns, banks have relied more heavily on restricted stock units when they’re handing out bonuses. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Untested Banks Find Demand for Risky AT1 Bonds
item.description: Investors are so eager to buy the riskiest bank debt that they’re snatching up securities even from unproven borrowers.
item.dc:creator: Tasos Vossos

media:content.media:description: A Metro Bank Holdings Plc bank branch in Chelmsford, UK, on Monday, July 22, 2024. Metro are due report their first half-year earnings on July 31.

item.title: Meyer Burger to Delay Results as Two Units File for Insolvency
item.description: Struggling solar-module manufacturer Meyer Burger Technology AG requested an extension of the deadline to present its 2024 financial results after its German units filed for insolvency proceedings.
item.dc:creator: Angela Cullen

media:content.media:description: A worker performs quality control on the production line for solar modules at the Meyer Burger Technology AG plant in Freiberg, Germany, on Jan. 18, 2022.

item.title: At 10 AM, Stock Options Soar as Retail Traders Unleash New Bots
item.description: When people talk about algorithmic traders, it evokes images of rooms full of math PhDs creating complex models that place huge trades in milliseconds after economic or earnings data is released. But now, it’s retail traders who are turning in droves to automated trading, building the kind of programs in their basements more associated with Wall Street banks than the Reddit thread r/wallstreetbets.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder

media:content.media:description: S&P 500 Options Volume per Minute in 2025

item.title: Thousands Rally in Bulgaria to Protest Plan for Euro Adoption
item.description: Thousands of people gathered in dozens of cities across Bulgaria to protest against the adoption of the euro as authorities prepare to switch to the European Union’s single currency early next year.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: A demonstration against Bulgaria entering the Eurozone in Sofia on May 31.

item.title: High Risk and High Reward of Undersea Cables
item.description: Undersea cables carry 99% of the world's internet traffic, but how do these cables work, and are they worth the investment? Google’s first employee of its subsea unit, Jayne Stowell weighs in on how the company paved the way for hyperscalers to take over an industry once controlled by telecom giants. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Adani Energy Approves Raising $502 Million Via Share Sale
item.description: Billionaire Gautam Adani-controlled Adani Energy Solutions Ltd. approved raising 43 billion rupees ($502 million) via a stake sale.
item.dc:creator: Saikat Das

media:content.media:description: Gautam Adani, chairman of Adani Group, at the Kumbh Mela festival in Prayagraj, Uttar Pradesh, India, on Jan. 21, 2025.

item.title: OPEC+ Agrees on Third Oil Supply Surge Despite Russia’s Qualms
item.description: OPEC+ agreed to surge oil output for the third month in a row despite reservations from key member Russia, doubling down on a historic policy shift that has sent crude prices sinking.
item.dc:creator: Fiona MacDonald, Salma El Wardany, Nayla Razzouk, Grant Smith

item.title: How Long Will It Take to Fix Air Traffic Control?
item.description: How long will it take to address the outages plaguing our air traffic control system? Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University Air Traffic Management Program Coordinator Michael McCormick says it won't happen overnight, even as the Trump administration calls for an overhaul of the system. (Source: Bloomberg)
